kmeans_metrics.Rmd

data("penguins", package = "modeldata")
penguins <- penguins %>% drop_na()

Setup 

kmeans_spec <- k_means(num_clusters = 3) %>%
    set_engine("stats") 
  
kmeans_fit <- kmeans_spec %>%
  fit(~ bill_length_mm + bill_depth_mm,
      data = penguins)

kmeans_fit %>% extract_centroids()
#> # A tibble: 3 × 3
#>   .cluster  bill_length_mm bill_depth_mm
#>   <chr>              <dbl>         <dbl>
#> 1 Cluster_1           50.9          17.3
#> 2 Cluster_2           38.4          18.3
#> 3 Cluster_3           45.5          15.7
kmeans_fit %>% extract_fit_summary()

Metrics 

kmeans_fit %>% within_cluster_sse()
#> # A tibble: 3 × 2
#>   .cluster    wss
#>   <fct>     <dbl>
#> 1 Cluster_1  618.
#> 2 Cluster_2  905.
#> 3 Cluster_3  742.
kmeans_fit %>% tot_wss()
#> # A tibble: 1 × 3
#>   .metric .estimator .estimate
#>   <chr>   <chr>          <dbl>
#> 1 tot_wss standard       2265.
kmeans_fit %>% tot_sse()
#> # A tibble: 1 × 3
#>   .metric .estimator .estimate
#>   <chr>   <chr>          <dbl>
#> 1 tot_sse standard      11216.
kmeans_fit %>% sse_ratio()
#> # A tibble: 1 × 3
#>   .metric   .estimator .estimate
#>   <chr>     <chr>          <dbl>
#> 1 sse_ratio standard       0.202
# kmeans_fit %>%
#   augment(penguins)
  
dists <- penguins %>%
  select(contains("bill")) %>%
  dist()

silhouettes(kmeans_fit, dists = dists)
#> # A tibble: 333 × 3
#>    cluster   neighbor  sil_width
#>    <fct>     <fct>         <dbl>
#>  1 Cluster_1 Cluster_2     0.675
#>  2 Cluster_1 Cluster_2     0.606
#>  3 Cluster_1 Cluster_2     0.547
#>  4 Cluster_1 Cluster_2     0.692
#>  5 Cluster_1 Cluster_2     0.592
#>  6 Cluster_1 Cluster_2     0.671
#>  7 Cluster_1 Cluster_2     0.647
#>  8 Cluster_1 Cluster_2     0.370
#>  9 Cluster_1 Cluster_2     0.589
#> 10 Cluster_1 Cluster_2     0.577
#> # … with 323 more rows
#> # ℹ Use `print(n = ...)` to see more rows

avg_silhouette(kmeans_fit, dists = dists)
#> # A tibble: 1 × 3
#>   .metric        .estimator .estimate
#>   <chr>          <chr>          <dbl>
#> 1 avg_silhouette standard       0.484

Comparison to auxilary variables

ALERT NAS ARE STUPID

penguins <- penguins %>%
  drop_na(bill_length_mm, bill_depth_mm) 

penguins %>%
  cbind(extract_cluster_assignment(kmeans_fit)) %>%
  enrichment(.cluster, species)

Cross-Validation

take the full data assignments as “ground truth”

Tuning

Traditional “elbow” plot:


results_wss <- c()
results_ratio <- c()

for (k in 2:10) {
  
  kmeans_spec_k <- k_means(num_clusters = k) %>%
    set_engine("stats") 
  
  kmeans_fit_k <- kmeans_spec_k %>%
    fit(~ bill_length_mm + bill_depth_mm,
        data = penguins)
  
  
  results_ratio <- c(results_ratio, sse_ratio(kmeans_fit_k))
  results_wss <- c(results_wss, wss(kmeans_fit_k))
}

plot(results_wss)
plot(results_ratio)

(Note that the totss aka residual ss is the same no matter what k, so these plots will be the same except the scale of the y-axis. I hypothesize ratio will be better for cross validation.)

What about by enrichment?


results_species <- c()

for (k in 2:10) {
  
  kmeans_spec_k <- k_means(num_clusters = k) %>%
    set_engine("stats") 
  
  kmeans_fit_k <- kmeans_spec_k %>%
    fit(~ bill_length_mm + bill_depth_mm,
        data = penguins)
  
  res <- penguins %>%
  cbind(extract_cluster_assignment(kmeans_fit_k)) %>%
  enrichment(.cluster, species)
  
  results_species <- c(results_species, res)

}
#> Warning in stats::chisq.test(.): Chi-squared approximation may be incorrect

#> Warning in stats::chisq.test(.): Chi-squared approximation may be incorrect

#> Warning in stats::chisq.test(.): Chi-squared approximation may be incorrect

plot(results_species)

Is there a penalized ChiSq type thing? Look into this.
